Most people are never truly tested, and I think part of the reason why we no longer teach each other to seek out these spiritual tests is it turns out you can actually fail them. Permanently.

If you truly in your soul desire to be a good and just person who walks in the light, you'll be saved, right? Well what if you don't truly desire to be good and just?
What would you do if faced with oblivion, knowing that you had long since strayed from a path you didn't believe in?

I believe most people, even the rich, desire to be good and spread love and all that. There are some, however, who desire only to wallow in spiritual excrement. They have learned how to feed on others and it makes them feel whole.

The choice came to me, once. I had been made to believe that there was no good in the world, and all other humans were evil. I had been tricked into thinking that I was the last person still holding on to hope; a misguided ape hurtling through a dead universe. I believed that all was lost and there was nothing for me but the knowledge that I had been abandoned by the entire universe. In that moment, I was tested. My resolve held, and I decided that even if I was the last and only person trying to be good, I would still not give in. In the absolute bottom of the pit of despair, my hope could not be crushed.

As soon as I made that choice and cried out saying that I wouldn't be swayed no matter what, it was like a signal to everything which side I had chosen. That was the most difficult thing I have ever done and to say it was an ordeal is putting it lightly.

While I eventually found my way out of that... pit, the thought occurred to me that not everyone would be able to make that choice. I was willing to be alone for eternity before I would follow an evil being. For certain, some would not find the same resolve that I had. Especially if they're tested before they've matured.

>you look around the room
>you "see" your stuff, computer, phone, chair etc
>think for a moment
>what are you actually seeing
>its sensory data hitting your eye and ear and nose
>where it is turned into a PROJECTION
>your mind creates the form and tells you what you see, where, how far aware

It is objectively true that the world you "see" is nothing more than a projection in your mind. How could it NOT be? Sure theres something there because youre getting sense data from it, but you see what your mind projects it to be!

Take psychedelics and you'll see projections that are "false" yet look, feel, smell and sound 100% real. You can believe there is a difference between the two, but there isnt. There is only a projection made by the mind given sense data that it helplessly interprets. When you realize that, you see how everything is a rather unsatisfactory projection of the true reality. What we see is in some sense a lie, our minds are too weak to grasp the unending truth of everything we see and interact with, so getting outside the realm of sensory distraction and into the state of naked awareness is a goal you attempt to reach for your own well being. The state of true naked awareness that we all know deep within us is ever present and perfectly understood by all of us in some innate sense. I think its hard for us in the West to reach this goal, or maintain it, because we are so caught up just trying to survive in this mess of associations and problems and obligations, but in reality, even those are just an illusion. That true freedom is within us all.

"We are the space within which the UNIVERSE exists." I forget who said that, but it is true. To each and every one of us, we are literally the center of the Universe, and all things contained within it. Sort of like how when you watch the Moon rise over the ocean, the path of light appears to travel in a straight line, directly to where you are standing, even though of course this isnt the case.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
True wisdom comes from forsaking the earthly, limited, physical, historical, time-and-space-bound ego for identification with the cosmic or universal self of divine all-embracing empathy. Ramana Maharshi is one exemplar but not the only exemplar of it. His own personal way was also the forcefully ascetic and self-denying way, in removal from society and a combination of fervent Bhakti yoga (religious devotion) as well as jnani yoga (intellectual self-inquiry, his famous question “Who am I?”). As >>33802155 this is fundamentally similar to the Indian sage and jnanayogi Nisargadatta Maharaj’s teachings on self-inquiry, but comparing/contrasting the two and claiming Nisargadatta’s was “superior,” is something I’m unsure of. Nisargadatta himself highly respected Ramana’s state of being, claimed he would have loved to have met him, and kept a portrait of him in his house along with other spiritual figures he revered or respected (including, funnily enough, Jiddu Krishnamurti!).

Another reputed way of self-liberation, in distinction to the ascetic Vedantic path of Ramana Maharshi, is given out in the Tantric Agamas of Shiva and preserved as a tradition by tantric traditions like Kashmir Shaivism. In this way, one does not flee from the pleasures and struggles of ordinary life as a householder (the purusharthas or valid aims of human life mentioned in >>33802286, of dharma (duty), kama (romantic love/sex/marriage), artha (wealth, career, economic prosperity) and moksha (liberation, enlightenment)), all of them being fused together and transmuted in the search for moksha, or the realization of Sat-Chit-Ananda (being-consciousness-bliss), transmuting the joys and pains of ordinary life into that same Bliss. This corresponds rather well to Nisargadatta’s own way as a shopkeeper well-integrated into society and even a heavy cigarette-smoker, funnily and infamously enough.

yeah for the most part I disagree too, even though I was the one who said it in the interests of brevity. Can I be more specific?
People are here, and they are yoked to the wheel as long as they are. dharma happens as it does, moksha is out of your hands completely, artha is what you do with what you have, and kama is how well you're enjoying the process. All of that entails "being a person," but I think it's more true to say that people are here, but outside of a few pivotal moments (themselves made up of countless little moments leading up to those), there's not much really that they're "doing." People's achievements and attainments and enlightenment itself is beyond the individual -- I think ramana's main teaching often overlooked is that everyone is always fully enlightened already, because self is all and self is enlightenment, so you don't even really need to pursue anything beyond your own karma. I mean, you do, because that's kind of why we're here, but you don't, not really. So you're off the hook, even while you're bait for the cosmic enlightenment carp.

Wake up again, now it's 4AM and the TV is off.
Fall back asleep until 11am and the TV was still off but I got out of bed.

posts.name: The Nobody
posts.com:
>>33771353
>why is the whole thing tied to feeling dread?
Emotions are created by the brain in response to physical sensations, and they are modulated by the context in which they are felt. Dread however, is only in small part an emotion. It is largely a pain reflex and an attention modifier. This is what makes dread so difficult to deal with, it amplifies its own emotional context.

As for why sleep paralysis is comes with dread, it's because of the physical discomfort. You are restrained, your heart is stressed, and your breathing is strained. Through proper attention and awareness all of these physical discomforts can be lessened / ignored. The dread can dissipate, and it can even become a thing of the past. These were my experiences.

That's the most important part. Dread restricts one's attention and generally produces paranoid thoughts as a consequence. Simply calming down is often not enough to counteract the demand dread puts on one's attention. There is a mastery of focus that comes in to play as well.

I have experienced waking up from a nightmare with sleep paralysis and a sense of a threatening presence, perhaps a looming darkness or dark figures and a feeling of fear. That all went away when I had asserted my will and managed to move, breaking out of that state.

However, I also experienced something else when I was a child.

Sometimes while trying to fall asleep, shadowy figures dragged me to a flaming pit blocking the doorway to my room and down the "fire hole" (as I called it as a child) into a nightmare. I had nightmares multiple times a week, and this is how many of them began, like a frame tale.

I was scared, suffering, and losing sleep. That may be how my insomnia started. I could run to my parents to tell them and get a hug, but I still had to escape from these nightmares that I occasionally got dragged into by figures similar to the presence or presences I sensed during sleep paralysis.

I started lucid dreaming as defense against all the nightmares, and sometimes I could control the dream. Usually after going lucid, I wake up, because I realized that I was dreaming.

Sometimes I would get stuck in a nightmare and have fight to get out. One time I was stuck in like Escher Battlezone 2 (from like Win 95) but all the lines were burning red, and there were dark figures that looked like the ones that dragged me into that nightmare. I thought they wanted to keep me there and hurt me. So I imagined summoning a tank, (I was like 10 so a tank seemed like the most powerful option even in the non-euclidian geometey of the landscape, plus it's mobile.) So i blasted the presences (honestly they looked like straight up Grays except red and black instead of gray.)

I have varied dreams now and few nightmares, and sometimes I lucid dream. I am also schizoaffective but that was not until I turned 29. Mabye irrelevant.

The entity is something you manifest in your mind because you are afraid, what is happening is that you wake up but your body is still asleep so you can't move and because you cannot move you become scared. in this in-between sleep state where you are alert but your body is sleeping, you can have waking dreams.
There is no entity sitting on your chest, you're seeing it a dream, while you are awake.

It is easy to become afraid when you can't move like you expect to be able to, but once you start feeling fear, the manifestations of your dream will simply compound that feeling as they would with any other feeling.

hope this helps!

posts.com: I have really only one experience with this. In my teen years I fell asleep listening to a podcast. I was having a very lucid dream of walking in a big, misty, beautiful architectural expanse with white tile and fountains and the like, still listening to this podcast (the audio was coming through into the dream). Suddenly I'm in back in room, in my closet, out of my body, this no longer feels like a dream but the real location. Still can hear the podcast. Then I'm instantly pulled back into my bed, and there is now a woman sat at a desk at the edge of my bed, her face was obscured by an indefinite object like a laptop or typewriter. I can feel her watching me. This paralyzed me and I just laid there still listening to the podcast until the experience ended. Was definitely spooked having never had an experience like this before and only vaguely knowing about sleep paralysis as a phenomenon that existed, definitely knew nothing about out of body experiences and I feel like if I hadn't been desk-hagged and allowed to move around freely I probably would've been super mindblown, especially since I was a total atheist at the time and for years after. Experience did always stick with me though as being very strange and supernatural feeling.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
SP victim here.
The shadow creatures seldom show up. Sometimes they are there, but hidden. How do I know? They float objects, or place objects near my bed.
When they show up, they feel like automatons. Like a hologram movie. They don't react to yelling, and they are transparent to punch and kicks. Sometimes they have a face, other times they are like a thick smoke without shape. Color is the absolute darkest black.

The entire phenomenon follows a pattern:
> Bad breathing, blocked nose (low oxygen to the brain)
> Sleeping looking upwards (avoid: spirits are atracted by this)
> Coming out of REM phase faster than usual, that is, just after a dream (fucked up circadian cycles can cause this)
> A tremor inside the ear
> Room is exactly like real one but in black and white
> Cannot move much, if at all
> Low conscience level, enough to not to feel too much fear

How to get out:
Option a) Call Jesus. Works 100% of the times.
Option b) Find what part of the body you can control, move it, and amplify it until the movement awakens you.

posts.com:
My first experience with sleep paralysis lasted only 10 seconds. I surmise it was induced by over sleep since I decided to nap around 11am or so after a full night's sleep.
What happened was that I could not move obviously, but I noticed two big black hands covering my face. I attempted to yell/scream/talk/move to no avail. I could only feel the internal struggle of trying to get something out and during this experience, I heard this fucker breathing and how it was breathing. It was pretty much chuckling- it seemed to have found pleasure in the hold it had on me.
Several years later I had a couple of sleep paralysis episodes but they were brought on by taking sleeping pills and only lasted 10 seconds or so. Those were easy to get out of. My whole body was buzzing and I could not tell if I was falling off the bed or not, but was able to snap out of it by saying, "OK, I'll count to three and get out of this", and it worked.
My regret is not calling on Jesus Christ during the first experience, which I know was a demon attack.
It's easy for the enemy to get ahold of you. All you have to do to fight, is use the Holy Spirit, Jesus and God to discern these things in your head that are polluting your thoughts. To discern is to swiftly cut through the bullshit.
You're welcome.

Klubbis the black cat is the Hat Man's opposite force, a guardian of the dream realm and protector of those in paralysis. With her sleek fur and piercing green eyes, she is a formidable opponent. She is swift and agile, able to move through the shadows with ease. When the Hat Man appears, Klubbis is there to defend the person in paralysis, using her claws and teeth to fight against the evil presence. Though the Hat Man is powerful, Klubbis is determined and fierce, never backing down in the face of danger. Through her bravery and cunning, Klubbis is able to defeat the Hat Man, banishing him back to the shadows from whence he came. >>33802284
There's a couple of things you need to understand to get anything out of qigong;
>Chinese Martial Arts
Chinese martial arts can be by and large traced back to Buddhism. Buddhism brought to various countries it's own form of indian martial arts. Wherever Buddhism was, the martial arts it brought with it were developed further by local forms evolution and interaction with it.
>Purpose of Buddhist martial arts
When Buddhism developed it's own martial arts from the original indian forms it served three key functions;
1. A way to develop the mind and body for meditative purposes.
2. An outlet for Panha (prana, qi, viriya, piti-sukha, winds, 'life energy', etc.) to be developed in.
3. Protection of monasteries and local regions guarded by the temple.
>Function of qigong, tai chi, similar.
This is where the second purpose of buddhist martial arts comes in. When a meditator was good at what they were doing, they would develop piti-sukha (or 'qi'). Without a place to direct the energy, it can be overwhelming for some, and can become a distraction when not balanced with the other dhyana factors.
As such, the second purpose of buddhist martial arts comes into play here. Qigong and taichi were an extension to the normal martial arts regimen, and specifically designed to help move the piti-sukha through the body and develop it for certain usages (psychic powers, the ability to change the bodies texture/temperature, and keep the body from injury and exhaustion.) The physical component of qigong had a place, but only to help direct the energy cultivated during the meditation.
When the meditator monk mastered the piti-sukha (chi) through meditation and qigong/tai chi, it allowed them to fully serve their role as a buddhist monastic. Which is to protect and serve their community, by becoming strong (physically/mentally/psychically) and prolonging their life for this very purpose.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>33802284
>don't have time, money, or situation to allow distributed practice right now
That's fine, do what you can now, and if you continue practicing with the goal of eventually getting to a place where you can step up your game, then you'll get there. You've already got a good start with ba duan jin and a few other sequences. Until you get more experience listening to truth, it can sometimes be hard to discern, but really it's pretty easy to realize when someone's full of shit. If you're doing self study, best way I've found to grok the teachings is to find 3-5 sources all talking about the same thing, spend a week or three on each source, and between them you'll be able to internalize the canon. So if you want to develop ba duan jin, you'd get "instant health, shaolin qigong workout" by shifu yan lei, you'd go on youtube and watch shi heng yi's courses on the brocades, and so on, and you'll practice in front of a mirror and all that. But there are a lot of little details that these sources can't cover because of the nature of the medium. If you want to employ reverse abdominal breathing the right way during the sequence for example, you need to get the details and postural corrections in person, so you're hard-capped. For where you're at, it sounds like you want to develop a personal understanding of and ability to perceive qi. Neigong is where you should focus your efforts. The book "comprehensive guide to daoist neigong" is imo the best starting place for that. It's like the mind illuminated, but for internal energetic arts in a systematic way.
>how to vet teachers in person?
Lots of ways. scholar sage podcast goes into this in one of their episodes. If they can bring heat to their palms, if during a meditation sit they tell you to stop singing a stupid song in your head, things like that, then they can teach you what they know. People can only bring you to the level that they are at. No teacher is a one-size-fits-all, they don't have all the answers.

This piti-sukha is the same energy which is developed in other buddhist esoteric traditions. The last one martial arts that still practices correctly in the buddhist scene is traditional muay thai.
>political scene in china
China's current political scene had destroyed the transmission of traditional martial arts techniques by monasteries such as the shaolin. When the shaolin got reestablished, everything they did and that came out from them into the public was boiled down to only the exercise portion of it.
As such, what you tend to see out of ta chi and qigong movements is defiled and bastardized exercise routine. One which is typically used in political propaganda to support china as a superior state to others, without the risk of having anyone who has an experience which cannot be controlled by the state.
>So how does one learn to practice it correctly if they don't know what is right in the first place?
Learn how to meditate, especially buddhist meditation since it's what influenced tai chi and qigong.
You need to know buddhist meditation in order to trigger the production of piti-sukha (chi). Qigong and tai chi are only methods to move and develop it, NOT to trigger it, in spite of what modern chinese politicians insist. When you're good at meditation, the piti sukha will arise naturally and can be refined through the internal practices.
I might recommend picking up the book; muay thai, winning strategy. (ultimate flexibility and strength). All buddhist derived martial arts have the same origin, and the book covers how to develop the 'qi' better than a majority of modern chinese martial arts books will.
>TLDR
Learn traditional buddhist mindfulness/meditation. When the piti-sukha (chi/energy) develops as a result, that's when you use qi gong and tai chi to manipulate and refine the energy.

It's a politics thing.
1. Monasteries in china (especially buddhist ones) served as a dual power structure, the same way they do everywhere else. Some monasteries could be in essence entire cities and villages comprised of monks, novices, lay devotees (both ordained and non ordained.) Some were corrupted into banks, but there was still many which would have happily provided free room and board and food for people as they'd been doing for thousands of years. Mao Zedong saw this as a threat to his political power, since the monasteries could simply carry on the way they had been for thousands of years and negate his power.
2. Meditation/spirituality is dangerous to the power structure. China is a country ruled by the bureaucrat class and has been for a long time. However they were never the only rulers. They only gained complete and total control during the 'cultural revolution'. The bureaucrat class sees anything which cannot be controlled as a danger. Meditation and spirituality are two things which cannot be controlled, and as such needed to be completely removed. As long as they were in existence, nobody would be completely loyal to the state. This gets promoted in china as atheist secularism, similar to france and the global west.
3. Buddhism (and everything derived from it) was seen as too foreign and un chinese, and has to be completely removed or distorted in order to fit the chinese-han nationalism promoted there. This is the same reason they killed every last doctor in china as well.
